frameDefinitions: The Performers, together with behind the scenes Personnel, execute a Performance according to a Script and/or Score.
This frame describes the Impression which a Figure, which can be a person, an organization, or an object, leaves with an Audience.
A Text is an entity that contains linguistic, symbolic information on a Topic, created by an Author at the Time_of_creation.
Artists work at various tasks that further the completion of a film, play, television show, or other similar Production.
A salient Subevent has a Pattern of recurrence within a larger Process.
A Communicator conveys a Message to an Addressee; the Topic and Medium of the communication also may be expressed.
frameExamples: He had an extremely fragile self - <t><fex name='Impression'>image</fex></t>
Steven Spielberg <t>directed</t> several films for Universal Pictures.
Tony's fingers tapped <t>rhythmically</t> on the keyboard
Let's hope it did n't have time to <t>communicate</t> any of its findings to its overlords.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Performer</fen> provides an experience for the <fen>Audience</fen>.
The <fen>Personnel</fen>, including writers, producers, stage hands, key grips, etc., contribute to the <fen>Performance</fen> without actually being directly perceived by the <fen>Audience</fen>.
The <fen>Audience</fen> experiences the <fen>Performance</fen>.
The experience generated by the <fen>Performer</fen>s and perceived by the <fen>Audience</fen> .

The (usually written) directions which instruct the <fen>Performer</fen>s on what actions to perform, when, and how.  It has many different names depending on the <fen>Type</fen> of <fen>Performance</fen> including <ment>script</ment>, <ment>screenplay</ment>, <ment>libretto</ment>, <ment>book</ment>, and <ment>choreography</ment>.
The <fen>Score</fen> may be performed in the <fen>Performance</fen>, either in isolation or accompanying actions and speech.
This role indicates the <fen>Type</fen> of <fen>Performance</fen>, including <ment>dance</ment>, <ment>theater</ment>, <ment>film</ment>, etc.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Performer</fen> to transmit the <fen>Performance</fen> to the <fen>Audience</fen>.
The entity (a person, organization, product, or event) for which the <fen>Audience</fen> has an <fen>Impression</fen>.
A person or group of people who have an <fen>Impression</fen> of a <fen>Figure</fen>.
A generalized conception of a <fen>Figure</fen> presented to or shared by an <fen>Audience</fen>.
The <fen>Text</fen> is the entity that contains linguistic information. This an incorporated role for each LU in this frame.
The region where the <fen>Text</fen> is sold, circulated, or otherwise popular.
The <fen>Artist</fen> works off-stage to help make the <fen>Production</fen>.
The <fen>Production</fen> is the final product put out by the off-stage (and on-stage) participants.
An <fen>Artist</fen> may be categorizedy by <fen>Type</fen>.
Often (especially with film or television) the <fen>Production</fen> is advertised and transmitted to the audience by the <fen>Distributor</fen>.
This role indicates the particular orgainzaion that makes the <fen>Production</fen>.
This role indicates the <fen>Medium</fen> in which a particular <fen>Artist</fen> works or a <fen>Production</fen> is made.
In screen performances, the <fen>Performer</fen> is filmed as he or she acts out a role with respect to the larger <fen>Production</fen>
The music which may be performed in the performance of the <fen>Production</fen>, either in isolation or accompanying actions and speech.
A <fen>Scene</fen> is a sub-part of a larger production.  In film, scenes are sometimes recorded independently, and later edited into the final movie.
This role indicates the time when the <fen>Production</fen> is made.
This role indicates the location of production.
The larger event that is characterized by the recurring Subevents.
The salient, punctual event that is construed as part of a <fen>Process</fen>.
The <fen>Pattern</fen> that can be detected in the recurrence of  the <fen>Subevent</fen>s of the <fen>Process</fen> .
The sentient entity that uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey a <fen>Message</fen> to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
<fen>Message</fen> is a proposition or set of propositions that the <fen>Communicator</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to believe or take for granted.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
The physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
The time at which the communication takes place.
The location where the act of communication occurs.
listRoleExamples: <fex>John Williams</fex> composed the soundtrack to Star Wars.
Ralph Smith produced <fex>the off-Broadway hit 'Why Is My Name Ralph?'</fex>.
Even desperate producers would never produce a film <fex>for that television station</fex>.
The latest performance produced <fex>by The Umbrella Thesbians</fex> was a major hit in France.
This particular scene was shot <fex>with a local choir and dancers</fex>.
Silence of the Lambs was filmed <fex>in 1991</fex>.
The rhythm <fex>of the rain falling on the roof</fex> kept me awake
The music had a driving rhythm
<fex>He</fex> finds it hard to communicate with people, not least his separated parents .
How do you communicate to them <fex>that you really like them</fex> ?
Had someone communicated to the capital <fex>about the flagrant disregard of the religious law</fex> ?
Opinions are usually communicated <fex>over the telephone</fex> and are often given within 24 hours.
